text: okay it's mark Wiens here in Bangkok
Thailand with Thai Street food recipes
right now I'm going to be making King
King pet die which is southern style
curry paste it's absolutely essential in
making many different southern Thai
dishes so we're gonna pound this up
pound up all these beautiful ingredients
and then after that we're gonna cook
some beautiful southern Thai dishes okay
so the first step is just to prepare all
the ingredients I've got all my
ingredients laid out on plates and I'm
just gonna first chop them up into
smaller little pieces to make it easier
to grind up by hand for this recipe I'm
going to be using five stalks of
lemongrass and the first thing to do is
just pull off those outer couple of
layers of the of the lemongrass skin
then you want to chop off the bottom of
the lemongrass stock and then just slice
it or shave it into really really thin
thin shavings in order to prepare your
galangal first chop off those red knobs
and you're looking for a piece that's
about a two-inch chunk then you can just
chop it into small pieces just so it's
easier to pound later pie shots are very
small almost the size of big grapes ah
but they are they pack a lot of flavor
in them and a lot of oils these are
delicious you're going to need five
small shallots for this recipe so you
can just cut off the ends and then peel
off the skin and then you can just slice
them into small pieces
we're also going to use two full heads
of garlic for this curry paste
so really however you want to do it if
you want to smash them if you want to
just peel them anyway just peel the skin
off the garlic and then set them aside
for pounding later one of the key
ingredient differences between southern
Thai curry paste and just regular or
northern or central type curry paste is
the use of turmeric just check that out
it's just beautifully rich and orange
and oily and if I just do that to my
fingers you can just see immediately my
finger turns orange the same thing goes
for the turmeric just really quickly
slice it up into smaller pieces and I
used about a handful of turmeric what
was about 50 grams for the kaffir lime
you want to slice it really carefully
and just try to get only that very outer
green bumpy skin without getting any of
that white pith attached to it it helps
to have a really sharp knife and then
just slice about half of the skin of the
lime now on to the challenging part and
the first thing to do is to pound the
tied driver chillies which entire known
as prick hang you might need to take it
down to the floor for some leverage and
also get get better pounding leverage as
well as more stability on the ground you
want to pound them for a few minutes and
soon the seeds should start coming out
and after a few more minutes you might
start to get a little bit of oil coming
out of the chillies probably after about
five or ten minutes of pounding you can
then add in the pretty mousse one which
is a slightly different variation or
variety of a Tyburn chilli but if you
cannot find prettiness one you can use
regular Thai bird chilies and now keep
on pounding for about ten or fifteen
minutes when your chilies are really
broken down then you can start adding
your turmeric lemongrass garlic shallots
galangal and the kaffir lime peel little
by little and really however you want to
add it just keep adding it little by
little my mortar actually got too full
so I had to take some of it out and put
it in a bowl and then I had the pound a
couple of batches you don't really need
to worry about the order of the
ingredients you just want to keep on
pounding until everything is ground up
and everything is is turning into a nice
buttery paste so it took me about an
hour to get to this point once your
paste is really starting to come
together and you can see it's turning
smoother and and getting more oily you
can then add in two tablespoons of whole
black peppercorns and about a half a
tablespoon of salt and then keep
pounding until all the peppercorns and
the salt are completely pounded into the
paste
literally took like an hour maybe an
hour and a half to pound at all but
right now it is just a beautiful buttery
buttery almost like margarine paste the
final step when your paste is pretty
much ready and a real buttery margarine
margarine consistency is to go in with
two tablespoons of guppy which is a
shrimp paste fermented shrimp paste this
is going to get more flavor to the to
the curry paste as well as some
saltiness some more saltiness you want
to make sure you put this in at the very
end because it gets really sticky pound
it kind of like push it in I can't
believe all those ingredients reduced
down to this buttery paste
look at that beauty one and a half hours
of work and sweat and and shoulder pain
for one bowl of gang pet die which
is southern Thai curry paste from this
southern Thai curry paste you can make a
number of different dishes including a
stir-fry called PUD pet and also you can
make quick bling you can also make
ganghwa which is a delicious southern
curry as well anyway lots of different
dishes we can make with this so this is
a wonderful wonderful one of my favorite
Thai curry pastes and of course you
could blend all the ingredients if you
don't have a lot of time or energy but
making it the traditional way in a
mortar using a mortar and pestle really
really enhances the flavor because then
you get all of the oils and you really
work the ingredients well but of course
many people will make it in a blender
nowadays and if you don't have the time
it actually is still worth it to make it
in a blender instead of buying it in a
can or a or a plastic tub this is the
good stuff right here oh god back you
